comment_text: Best tips: 1) Link variables to needed equations: Write a column: descriptive name, variable = value (or =? if value not given), and dimensions. e.g. rocket acceleration, a= 3.2 m/s^2. Link each variable to a relevant equation. The solution will be a product or sum of the identified equations.  2) Dimensional analysis. In the column, find a given variable that shares one or more dimensions of the answer, use that variable or a reciprocal of the variable.  Find the next variable as a factor to remove any unwanted dimensions.  This will tell you what factors must be multiplied together to get the right answer.  Example: The answer is velocity (m/s) so I need something with (m) or (s) so I choose acceleration (m/s^2).  I need to remove seconds so I multiply by time (s) to get the needed answer's dimension so (m/s)= (m/s^2)*(s) or velocity = acceleration * time. 3) Unfolding:  Replace the answer by its definition i.e. a sum or product of variables.  Look to the column and substitute values as needed to get the answer.

I got a D- in my first Calc I class. I had to re-take the class, and discovered that the style used by the second teacher made all the difference, and I got an A. The first teacher was the head of the math department, and the second teacher was a graduate student. Somehow, the graduate student just had a teaching style that worked much better for me.

I squeaked through the first time on Calc II with a C. But I had the same problem with Calc III and I had with Calc I, and so I had to re-take it also. And I happened to get the same grad student as my teacher, and got an A the second time around. His teaching methods really resonated with me.

Differential Equations I was super tough, but again I managed to squeak through with a C. And that was as far as I was required to go in math for my BSCS degree, although if I had done another 5 hours of higher level undergraduate math, I could have gotten a double degree.

But by far the worst class I took was Physics I. I probably should have gotten a D, but I think the teacher took pity on me that my grandfather had just died, so he gave me a C-, which was technically still good enough for my degree.

I've always enjoyed certain aspects of physics, but never the math behind it. IMO, that's what computers are for.

OK, almost three years too late, so no one will see this, but when you say "F=ma" and then write "the force exerted on an object is equal to the mass of the object multiplied by the object's acceleration." this is in fact incorrect. If it were true, the force of gravity exerted on me right now would be zero, as my acceleration is zero (sitting in a chair). It is very important, especially in an educational physics video, to say "F net" or "the net force" or "the sum of all forces". Please. As a high school physics teacher...please! I wish more college courses had different evaluation options for people with different learning strengths and weaknesses. Like if you have horrible test anxiety, you should be able to have your homework grades be worth more than your exams, or if you're like me and struggle with regularly having the energy to do weekly homeworks, you should be able to have the exams be worth more than the homeworks. You're the one paying to go to college (at least here in the US), so you should get to decide how you are graded.

For example, in me senior year as a math undergraduate I took the complex analysis series. The courses had homework assignments due each week but they weren't graded. You were encouraged to do them, but obviously they wouldn't impact your grade if you didn't. I did not do a single homework for those courses whatsoever. And of course I got an A in those classes because I aced the midterm and final and didn't have any missing or hastily finished homework assignments weighing down my grade. Fast forward to winter 2021, as a graduate math student I recently finished a functional analysis course where there were graded weekly homeworks that in total weighed almost as much as the final exam. I turned in 5 out of the 8 homeworks, but I got an 88%, 108%, and 95% on the two midterms and final respectively, and I earned a B for the course. It just demonstrates that you can learn everything you're supposed to learn for a course and still be shortchanged because the structure of the course prevents some learning and preparation styles from succeeding.

tldr: you shouldn't have to develop an elaborate studying scheme or cram an entire semester's worth of material the night before an exam to do well in a course if the exam freaks you out, and you shouldn't be forced to turn in assignments in a consistent manor if you're unable to develop that kind of incredibly robotic habit from the get go. You should definitely be held accountable for the way you want to be evaluated to prove you've learned your stuff, but the way in which you are should be wholly your choice.

I stumbled onto this video. It gave me a chuckle. I went into the 8.012 final needing something like a 40% to guarantee an A on the semester curve (assuming everyone else got 100, and if we had been on grades ... we were on pass/fail freshman year). I got a 10% - but class ave was like a 12% or 15% [that was probably brought up substantially by the 2 or 3 people who did really well! - I knew a guy who aced it.]

I remember one of the problems had something to do with the motions of a pencil if it fell from an upright position off the edge of a desk. I was sitting there - in the middle of the exam! - dropping my pencil off my desk in 26-100, trying to get some insight! There were too many unknowns in my mind. How does the pencil even start falling off the desk? Is it pushed at its center of gravity? Was it pushed it at its uppermost point? What about the impulse imparted? Were you supposed to assume an infinitesimal deflection in the angle and evolve the motion from there? Were you supposed to assume some initial conditions and write the general expression? ...

In retrospect I think the problem with the exam was not so much not understanding the physics, or how to do the math, it was recognizing what simplifying assumptions the problem writer intended. This was a big part of my growth at MIT, and probably most students: learning how to reduce a problem down to its essential features to a point where it can be modeled and solved.

I noticed a few differences with the 8.012 exam you showed. We had no multiple choice! That probably would have gotten me above 10%! I think there were fewer questions - maybe 3 or 4. I don't remember any cheat sheet of formulas; you either remembered them, derived them, or were out of luck.

8.012 was a good class. Could have had a lot more demos! I feel I missed out on Lewin's 8.01 demos.

You should get a good book and work out the exercise problems, if possible all of them. When I did my undergraduate Mechanical Engineering, this was the method I used. The same in Graduate school as well. Repetition makes the material second nature. Doing so will set you up with many Aha moments to understand deeper concepts. As the great mathematician Halmos said, never look at the solution to a problem, solve it first. If you cant get it, look for a hint or part of the solution and trudge along. At the end of the day, you need to feel comfortable with the material so as to be able to think conceptually about it.

It's unfortunate that through years of mostly unintentional subliminal indoctrination, students feel compelled to start writing their solutions on the exam handout within the limited space under the question. Why in the world would you do this? The best tip to reduce algebra and arithmetic errors, improve clarity and problem understanding, is to do all your work on separate blank sheets of paper. "Step away from the exam - there's nothing to see here!" Why cripple yourself with artificial boundaries? You're in college now and expected to start thinking independently. Giving yourself space makes you feel more relaxed, more observant, and more organized. Draw your diagrams as big as you can. No one ever flunked out of school because they made their annotations easier to read. Best of all, graders like easy to read answers too! A frustrated grader is a vindictive grader.

So do it. Control your destiny. It's a win^2!

The second part of the block through the disk oscillaton problem is really straightforward though girl. The total system is isolated so the center of mass's position is constant and therefore the period of oscillation of the block and disk are equal. The amplitudes of the block and disk are z_(disk) and delta h with their relation being set by the condition that the center of mass stay fixed.

You would need a third perturbing body to make the periods of the block and disk no longer equal. I'm sure this is all straightforward to you now and under the pressure of examinations basic ideas like this seem to the last thing one notices.

I'm a mechanical engineer and couldn't understand why on earth her answer regarding the rolling tire was wrong. In an ideal case, you certainly don't need friction between the contact surfaces to maintain constant-velocity no-slip rolling. Then I looked at the picture a bit closer and realized that the direction of rotation was actually clockwise and not counter-clockwise; the tire is slipping due to the velocity difference between the contact surfaces, which means there is indeed a friction force acting on the tire and the direction of this force is to the right.

I was a physics and math major in the slide rule days.  In a physics class they passed back the tests, mine was a 35 (out of 100).  I thought "i'm hosed"..  However it turns out I was the highest score in the class.  I certainly do not miss the tests.  After a full career, I have to say none of the physics and math was directly used by me in business (in technology/software) but the reasoning that I learned was used every day.

The biggest tip, that I would give, is "DON'T PANIC".  Find something you can do and start with that.  In my second semester Calculus course, (back right after calculus was invented, I guess), we had 6 people at the final.  One threw his paper in the air and said "F..... it" and walked out.  One just sat there and started crying, and one just sat there tapping a pencil on the desk and not even looking at the paper.  I suddenly realized that by doing anything at all, I had already beaten the grade of over half the class.  I looked for something I knew how to do and after I found it, breezed through the rest of it.   In my first Physics test for Physics majors, by the way, I believe I beat your score.  I got a 36.  After a curve, that turned out to be a B-.  Though I switched to Engineering in grad school and later got an MBA, I'm most proud of my Physics degree.  Keep physicsing!

The key is not to study to the test, but to the professor.

Professors have three key attributes: they are very intelligent, very arrogant, and very lazy (particularly when it comes to distractions, like teaching). Their coursework and tests are a reflection of what they think you should understand about the course because they are a reflection of what they understand about the course. You need to retrieve not just any test to review, but tests that particular professor issued in previous years. He won’t write the same questions as before, but they’ll be variations on a common theme, and because professors are lazy they’ll tweak the problem just enough to make it look different but not so much that they can’t reference last year’s solution set to make grading easy.

Other than that, great video. It was a disturbing reminder of my own horrors of test taking throughout my academic physics career.

Interesting comment about the conceptual physics, I have found that in certain circumstances I like teaching conceptual physics more than calculus based physics for exactly that same reason. However I feel that physics/engineers who need to take the calculus based one would really benefit a lot from learning the concepts behind the physics before doing the physics (not sure why more time isn't given for that... instead you have instructors trying to cram in absolutely useless except for 1%ers out there stuff like the rocket equation). However as one who also has taught the conceptual physics lab class, part of me feels the majority of those students really get hung up on any sort of math that's necessary to calculate a predicted outcome regardless of how simple the math is.


As to practice problems, that's great but I've seen so many students fall into the trap of learning how to do the problem in one particular way that they think that every problem works out that same way.


Overall though, MIT physics should not be harder than say SUNY physics or Padonk Idaho Community College physics for the same class level, the material is the material physics isn't different, however professors with the sink or swim mentality as they become "more prestigious" of an institution, and while yeah the ones that come out of it often do great but are they really any better than ones who didn't? Another piece of advice: the units involved are in a way more important than the values involved. If the answer requires kilopascals and your answer comes out in joules, you are probably using the wrong formulae, or you flubbed it on your calculation.

On the larger scale, the best thing you can do to prepare for any exam is develop self-assessment. In the video, you talk about doing practice problems and looking at old exams so you can try to answer some problem with your knowledge so you can determine how your knowledge lines up with how you need to present that knowledge. If, during this time, you realize a lapse or gap in that ability to present it, you can highlight what you need to focus on. This works in many other courses other than just math-related courses, as well, although the practice problems may not be as plentiful, or as related without being exactly the same.

Try these problems. Work yourself into a point where you don't know how to answer something, because then you know how you need to adjust from there to improve yourself.

As Nelson Mandela stated: The greatest glory in living lies not in never falling, but in rising every time we fall.

Take the practice attempts, and fall while doing so. It gives you the opportunity to rise and you are better as you step forward from there.

Although that's just my advice from being a professor for Anatomy & Physiology for about a decade.

If you have a few of them, do 1 to see how the questions are normally asked, then give yourself a practice exam in exam conditions. If you want to take it a step further, try to think like a lecturer and think about what questions you would put on the paper. In high school I was always good at math. When I got to college, I did ok in calculus, but to be honest I didn't retain any of it. It just wasn't presented in an engaging way. But the college math course that gave me the most trouble was linear algebra. I just continuously got Cs on the tests. I felt completely unmoored in the class. Things were presented without connecting them together. I felt like "why do I need to know this" a lot! When I got to the final, I said to myself "I've never blown up a math course before, and I'm not starting now." So I turned to the first page of the book and started skimming. When I came across something that I didn't understand, I slowed down and read it more closely. When I finished a chapter, I would look at its problems. If I thought I knew how to solve a problem, I skipped it and instead focused on problems I didn't know how to solve. Ultimately, I got a A on the finally and, who ever graded it wrote, "a much improved result" next to the grade. I've never needed Linear Algebra again, but the lesson on how to study has stayed with me.

My lightbulb moment in my approach to exams (esp. math & physics) was to realise that the practise problems given throughout the course were designed to give you practice in the concepts the lecturer wanted you to know - so I would study by making sure I understood the practice & assignment problems, only then would I do the past exams for at least the last 2-3 years. The technique came through spectacularly in my last year of high school where there were two mid-terms (mid-year & trial HSC exams for Aussies in the 90's) before the final (HSC) exam. I correctly assumed that the trial HCS physics exam would not cover the material already tested in the mid-year exam and focussed my studies on the newer material completely ignoring the previously tested concepts - I killed the trial HSC - topped the class! There was also an electronics exam in fist year uni where my study notes completely matched up with the order & subject matter of the exam questions! This technique never failed me right through uni (pity it couldn't be applied to my HSC English exam though - failed that one!)

I remember my college honors physics class where the "blue book" (essay) tests had 4 questions, with a base scoring was 25% for a C, 50% for a B, and 75% for an A, but sometimes they'd grade lower on an extra hard test. Certainly knowing the average scores helped my wounded pride. OTOH, there was often one student (Asian) who'd get 100%, so the rest of us always knew we could do better.

Best approach I found was Revise & Reduce then cram constantly, even down to the final walk to the desk I'd have record cards in front of me and I'd be saying key points to myself.

Mathematics and Physics and other hard sciences are more like studying music than other subjects. You should not need to specifically revise before an exam and stress out at that point. Like a musician learning to perform eight pieces over eight weeks, they are not just going to listen to a recording (read an example) and think they are going to know it. And they are not going to learn to perform a piece over a week, practicing nothing else and then forget about it until the day before the concert. You practice everything continuously even if you spend more time on the newer pieces. The exam then just becomes another practice day.

At 3:10 it took me back to school. The physics teacher liked this problem (the mass and velocities were given, but I can't recall them).
A steam locomotive with a known weight is travelling on a straight and level track at 60mph.
In the middle of the track is a water trough 440 yards long.
A water scoop is lowered in the trough and picks up water at a given rate.


The question was 'what addition power in BHP has to be developed to maintain speed?'
It was a trick question as, if you knew your formulae, everything cancelled out except the length of the trough, the units were, of course bhp.

It was like this. There is a disc that is rotating and in one moment a chunk of this disc is cut from the disc.
